instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: 820 4924 dead
threads.message: 820 4924 no power, 12.59v ppbus, 3.42v pp3v42, 5v and 3.3v on s5 lines. Missing S4. Machine was water damaged sometime in the passed. Apparently the board was cleaned by another shop, and it worked for a while, now its dead.

threads.title: 820 4924 dead
threads.message:
Oeiginal 85W charger?
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
Also check all RTC signals.

threads.title: 820 4924 dead
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.384v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.318v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 3.319v
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.321v

Unfortunately I do not have a scope to check RTC signals

threads.title: 820 4924 dead
threads.message:
There is only one oscillation to control with o-scope; 32KHz from pin 12/<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.
You can post DC voltage at least; 0.45V is a good aproximation.
The other 4 signals are on page 12 and no need o-scope at all...

threads.title: 820 4924 dead
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> .406v
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.320v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.321v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCST_L</SIGNAL> 3.31v

Are these the ones I am looking for, did I miss any? Also while I was taking these voltages the fan randomly kicked on and now I have my s4 lines back...

threads.title: 820 4924 dead
threads.message: Now, I am still getting fan spin, but no display, and no chime. Vcore is present...

threads.title: 820 4924 dead
threads.message:
You can try to heat/reflow CPU and SMC with good flux.
May be just crap remained under chips.
Can also be BIOS issue.
Do you get high level at pin 7/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?
Check all SPI termination resistors, page 47.
